newsitem.title: USA: Crude oil prices drop sharply, gold and coffee fall.
newsitem.headline: Crude oil prices drop sharply, gold and coffee fall.

text.p: Crude oil prices dropped to their lowest level in months on Wednesday as news of growing supplies and the end of the winter heating season fueled selling by speculators.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for delivery in May closed at $19.47 a barrel, down 81 cents and its lowest closing price since August 30, 1996.
That price was also the lowest for a spot or first month delivery of crude oil on the exchange since March 4, 1996, when oil closed at $19.20 a barrel.
Pressured by the selling in crude oil, May delivery gasoline closed 2.06 cents lower at 60.61 cents a gallon and May heating oil down 1.43 cents at 52.52 cents a gallon.
Gasoline prices typically rise in the spring ahead of the summer driving season, when gasoline demand peaks.
However, the American Petroleum Institute's weekly oil inventory data for the week ended March 28 showed U.S. refineries working at a strong 93.6 percent of capacity.
While gasoline and heating oil stocks fell slightly last week, stocks of crude oil grew 6.4 million barrels compared to the one to three million barrel rise expected by traders.
Imports rose sharply to 7.7 million barrels a day from 6.8 million due to an influx of West African crude oil.

"I think this was a recognition of the bearish API numbers which indicated the market is well supplied. We have known this for some time, though," said Prudential Securities analyst Richard Redash in New York.
"With gasoline falling with crude, we have removed from the market one bullish underpinning that the market has been relying on to take us higher," Redash said.
Precious metals prices also slipped as speculators sold, with gold for June delivery at the Commodity Exchange in New York closing down $2.60 an ounce at $352.10.
May silver ended down 13.5 cents at $4.87 an ounce.
Traders cited selling by commodity investment funds as the cause of the weakness and said precious metals were likely to steady after those professional investors eased up.

"Overall, though, the precious metals complex still looks to be consolidating the gains made earlier this year, helped perhaps by a weakening equities market," said Andre Dimino, New Jersey based fund manager with Apostle Capital Management.
Treasury bond yields were little changed Wednesday, but stock market values continued to slide following last week's monetary policy tightening by the U.S. Federal Reserve.

"If (U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan) Greenspan thinks inflation is rising, you would think gold prices would rise," said Hans Kashyap, president of Analytics Research Corp of Maryland. "But gold is not much of an inflation hedge anymore, only perhaps a catastrophe hedge."
At the Coffee Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, coffee futures closed lower despite a strike by stevedores on Wednesday at Santos port in Brazil, the top coffee exporter.
May delivery coffee closed at 193.15 cents a pound, down 1.15 cents.
The strike in Santos was scheduled to last 48 hours and could spread to national level on Friday if the dispute is not resolved, the stevedores' union said Wednesday.
"The strike does not look to be a serious situation and I'm not sure how much it will impact coffee shipments," said Dean Witter analyst Steve Platt. "Typically, these strikes do not last that long.
At the Chicago Board of Trade, soybean futures rose to new 8-1/2 year highs on fears that the strike by Brazilian stevedores would go national on Friday.
May soybeans closed up eight cents a bushel at $8.83-1/2, the highest closing price since September 1988.
"There will be some strikes in Brazil," said Bob Lekberg, analyst with Goldenberg-Hehmeyer. "Whether that impacts the port of Paranagua is uncertain but that was still a sustaining factor."
Paranagua handles the bulk of soybean exports from Brazil, which ranks second to the United States as a soy exporter.
